awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Vibration Measurement System for Enhancement of Research and Education at Saint Louis University
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) project supports the acquisition of a state-of-the-art vibration measurement system to enable fundamental research and education in engineering and biology.  The instrumentation will enable researchers to develop a fundamental understanding of how vibrations propagate in complex environments, leading to enhanced man-machine interfaces, more efficient renewable energy sources and new ultrasound-based therapeutic strategies. The instrumentation will catalyze interdisciplinary research collaborations among thirty faculty, staff and students and with industrial partners. The instrumentation will be integrated into coursework and labs and will enhance outreach activities for K-12 students and underrepresented minorities.
 
 
These investigations will support the development of models for vibration propagation through complex systems and the development of technologies that use vibrations in novel ways.  The projects will acquire high-resolution, non-contact, full-field data on structures that span size, scale, and material properties: from microscopic to larger amplitude, from short to long range, from low to high frequencies, and through varying mediums. These data will enable researchers to develop better models to understand (1) ultrasonic vibrations as it relates to surface haptic technologies; (2) vibrational communication in insects and arachnids; (3) insights into physical interactions between ultrasound and porous structures for bone healing; and (4) new designs for nature-inspired wind turbine blades.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
In this award, a Polytec PSV-500-H scanning laser doppler vibrometer system was acquired at Saint Louis University (SLU) and installed in the new state-of-the-art Interdisciplinary Science and Engineering Building on SLU’s campus. The scanning LDV system enables researchers to make non-contact, full-field measurements of vibrations across a variety of materials and surfaces, providing insights into the dynamics of both small and large scale motions. This system has enabled interdisciplinary research teams to collect novel measurements in a number of engineering and science applications including Biomedical Engineering, Mechanical Engineering, Aerospace Engineering, and Biology.  Results from the acquisition of this data have enabled research teams to investigate how vibrations propagate on touchscreens that have become ubiquitous in our society to understanding how insects communicate via vibrations in their natural environments (see Figure 1). While the COVID-19 pandemic has limited exposure and usage of the system to date, over 20 SLU faculty, staff, and students have been trained on the system, providing a unique skillset that has enhanced both research and education at SLU. As we move toward a new normal with more in-person educational and research experiences regaining momentum, the scanning LDV will be used extensively to support multi-institutional academic collaborations, cultivating a “hub” for high-resolution, full-field, vibration-based measurements across industry in the midwest, and crafting state-of-the-art educational experiences to support undergraduate and graduate STEM students and the general public.


Last Modified: 11/19/2021
Modified by: Jenna Gorlewicz

Image
  • Figure 1. The acquired Polytec Scanning LDV system being used to measure vibrations on a leaf in the insect vibration communication project (left) and to analyze the wave propagation across the leaf and plant stem (right).
    CHROME Lab - SLU
    Copyrighted
    Jenna Gorlewicz
    Polytec Scanning LDV System being used for measurement on a plant leaf
